description: Borrowed from Latin cista, from Ancient Greek κίστη (kístē). Doublet of chest.

entries.meaning: (historical, Ancient Greece) A small receptacle for sacred utensils carried in festivals in Ancient Greece.

description: Borrowed from Welsh cist (“chest”) (see kistvaen), from Latin cista (“chest, casket”), see above.

entries.meaning: (archaeology) A crypt cut into rock, chalk, or a tree trunk, especially a coffin formed by placing stone slabs on edge and topping them with a horizontal slab or slabs.
